title: Waters Recede from Earth
description: In Noah's 601st year, he removes the ark's covering and sees the surface of the ground is dry, marking the recession of floodwaters.

title: Erection of the Tabernacle
description: God commands Moses to set up the tabernacle on the first day of the first month in the second year after the exodus, establishing the central place of worship.

title: Selection of Passover Lamb
description: On the tenth day of the first month, the Israelites are instructed to select a lamb for the Passover sacrifice, preparing for the deliverance from Egypt.

title: Crossing the Jordan River
description: The Israelites cross the Jordan River on the tenth day of the first month, entering the Promised Land after 40 years in the wilderness.

title: Haman's Decree Issued
description: On the thirteenth day of the first month, the king's scribes write and seal Haman's command to destroy all Jews in the Persian empire.

title: Passover Observance
description: The Passover is observed on the fourteenth day of the first month, commemorating the sparing of Israelite firstborns during the final plague on Egypt.

title: Exodus from Egypt Begins
description: On the fifteenth day of the first month, the Israelites depart from Egypt following the Passover, beginning their journey to the Promised Land.

title: Census of Israel Ordered
description: On the first day of the second month in the second year after the exodus, God commands Moses to conduct a census of the Israelites in the wilderness of Sinai.

title: Second Passover for the Unclean
description: Those who are ceremonially unclean or on a journey observe the Passover on the fourteenth day of the second month, ensuring inclusivity.

title: Great Flood Begins
description: In Noah's 600th year, on the seventeenth day of the second month, the fountains of the deep burst forth and rain begins, initiating the global flood.

title: Departure from Mount Sinai
description: On the twentieth day of the second month in the second year after the exodus, the cloud lifts from the tabernacle, signaling the Israelites' departure from Sinai.

title: Earth Completely Dries After Flood
description: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month in Noah's 601st year, the earth is fully dry, allowing Noah and his family to exit the ark.

title: Mordecai's Decree for Jewish Defense
description: On the twenty-third day of the third month, the king's scribes write Mordecai's command allowing the Jews to defend themselves against their enemies.

title: Jerusalem's Walls Breached
description: On the ninth day of the fourth month during Zedekiah's reign, the famine-stricken city of Jerusalem is breached by the Babylonians.

title: Death of Aaron
description: Aaron ascends Mount Hor and dies on the first day of the fifth month in the fortieth year after the exodus, marking the end of his priestly service.

title: Ezra Arrives in Jerusalem
description: Ezra arrives in Jerusalem on the first day of the fifth month after departing Babylon, bringing reforms and teachings of the law.

title: Burning of the First Temple Begins (587 BC)
description: On the seventh day of the fifth month, Nebuzaradan begins burning Solomon's temple, the king's house, and all houses in Jerusalem.

title: Destruction of the First Temple (587 BC)
description: The First Temple is destroyed by the Babylonians under Nebuchadnezzar on the 9th of Av. Historical expectation suggests Jehoiarib (Course 1) was serving, as with the Second Temple's fall on the same date 657 years later.

title: Destruction of the Second Temple (70 AD)
description: The Second Temple is destroyed by the Romans under Titus on the 9th of Av. Historical testimony confirms that Jehoiarib (Course 1) was serving in the priestly rotation when the Temple fell, providing a critical anchor point for calculating the 24-course priestly cycle.
quote: The same month and day were now observed, as I said before, wherein the holy house was burnt formerly by the Babylonians.

title: Burning of the First Temple (586 BC)
description: On the tenth day of the fifth month (parallel account), Nebuzaradan burns the temple and city of Jerusalem.

title: Resumption of Temple Rebuilding
description: On the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month in Darius's second year, the people resume work on the house of God following Haggai's prophecy.

title: Completion of Jerusalem's Walls
description: Nehemiah completes the rebuilding of Jerusalem's walls on the twenty-fifth day of the sixth month (Elul) after 52 days of work.

title: Feast of Trumpets
description: A holy convocation with trumpet blasts is held on the first day of the seventh month, serving as a memorial and day of rest.

title: Renewal of Burnt Offerings
description: From the first day of the seventh month after the return from exile, the Israelites begin offering daily burnt offerings, reestablishing temple worship.

title: Day of Atonement
description: On the tenth day of the seventh month, the people afflict their souls and the high priest makes atonement for Israel in this annual day of fasting and repentance.

title: Sabbath Year Debt Release
description: On the Day of Atonement in the Sabbath Year (Year of Release), all debts among the people are to be forgiven. This is YHWH's time of release. Yeshua proclaimed 'the year of the Lord's favor' from Isaiah 61 in Luke 4 during a Year of Release.

title: Proclamation of Jubilee
description: The trumpet of the jubilee is sounded on the tenth day of the seventh month during the Day of Atonement, proclaiming liberty throughout all the land and return of property. All Hebrew servants are freed and land returns to original family ownership. Isaiah 61 prophesies of this ultimate release.

title: Yeshua Proclaims the Year of the Lord's Favor
description: In the synagogue at Nazareth, Yeshua reads from Isaiah 61 and declares 'Today this Scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing.' He proclaims liberty to captives and the year of the Lord's favor—the Year of Release commanded by Torah. The crowd, enraged, attempts to throw him off a cliff like the scapegoat, but he passes through their midst.
quote: The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim liberty to the captives and recovering of sight to the blind, to set at liberty those who are oppressed, to proclaim the year of the Lord's favor.

title: Feast of Tabernacles Begins
description: The Feast of Tabernacles commences on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, a seven-day celebration of dwelling in booths to remember the wilderness journey.

title: First Temple Dedication & Priestly Cycle Begins
description: Solomon dedicates the First Temple during the Feast of Tabernacles. The Ark is placed in the Most Holy Place and the glory of the LORD fills the Temple so that the priests cannot stand to minister. All priests had sanctified themselves and 'did not then wait by course' (2 Chr 5:11). After a 14-day celebration ending on the 23rd, the regular priestly rotations began with Jehoiarib (Course 1), establishing the 24-course weekly cycle that continued until 70 AD.
quote: And it came to pass, when the priests were come out of the holy place, that the cloud filled the house of the LORD, so that the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud: for the glory of the LORD had filled the house of the LORD.

title: Public Torah Reading (Sabbath Year)
description: At the end of every seven years, during the Feast of Tabernacles in the Year of Release, the Torah is read publicly before all Israel—men, women, children, and strangers—so that they may hear, learn, and fear YHWH.

title: Ark Rests on Ararat
description: On the seventeenth day of the seventh month, the ark comes to rest on the mountains of Ararat as the floodwaters continue to recede.

title: Jeroboam's Idolatrous Feast
description: King Jeroboam ordains a feast on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, imitating the Feast of Tabernacles but leading Israel into idolatry.

title: Prophecy to Zechariah
description: On the fourth day of the ninth month in Darius's fourth year, the word of the Lord comes to Zechariah regarding fasting and obedience.

title: Siege of Jerusalem Begins
description: On the tenth day of the tenth month in Zedekiah's ninth year, Nebuchadnezzar begins the siege of Jerusalem, leading to its eventual fall.

title: Moses Addresses Israel
description: On the first day of the eleventh month in the fortieth year after the exodus, Moses speaks to the Israelites, recounting their journey and God's commands.

title: Ezekiel's Prophecy Against Tyre (Babylon the Great)
description: In the 12th year of Jehoiachin's exile—the year after the First Temple fell—Ezekiel prophesies against Tyre. While partially fulfilled historically by Nebuchadnezzar and Alexander, the 'never rebuilt' clause points typologically to Babylon the Great's final destruction (Revelation 17-18).
quote: I am against you, O Tyre, and I will raise up many nations against you, as the sea brings up its waves... thou shalt be built no more: for I the LORD have spoken it.

details.heading: "Never be rebuilt" as permanent, end-times desolation
details.text: Ezekiel 26:14 says Tyre 'shall never be rebuilt' and 'be no more forever' (cf. v. 21), yet modern Tyre exists as a city. This suggests the prophecy has a dual/typological layer: partial historical fulfillment (Nebuchadnezzar, Alexander), but ultimate total/irreversible ruin in the future—like Babylon the Great's final fall ('found no more forever,' Rev 18:21).

details.heading: Symbolic 'bare rock' and fishing nets
details.text: The site becomes a bare rock for nets (Ezek 26:4-5,14), symbolizing utter stripping of glory/power. Babylon the Great ends similarly—utterly desolate, mourned by merchants, never restored (Rev 18:17-19,21).

details.heading: Commercial pride and global trade parallels
details.text: Tyre's wealth from worldwide merchants (Ezek 27) mirrors Babylon the Great's luxury trade list (Rev 18:11-13). Both are proud empires judged for exploiting nations/God's people.

details.heading: Gloating over Jerusalem's fall
details.text: Tyre rejoices at Jerusalem's ruin for gain (Ezek 26:2), typifying Babylon the Great's spiritual/economic opposition to saints (Rev 17:6; 18:24).

details.heading: Multi-nation waves of judgment
details.text: 'Many nations' attack like sea waves (Ezek 26:3); Babylon the Great falls when kings/beast turn on her (Rev 17:16-17), fulfilling the 'many nations' in an end-times context.

details.heading: Satanic ruler behind the city
details.text: Ezekiel 28 (tied to Tyre oracle) describes the king as a fallen cherub in Eden (v. 12-19), linking to satanic influence. Babylon the Great rides the beast (Satanic power, Rev 17:3-7), making Tyre a type of the final Antichrist system.

details.heading: Revelation's heavy borrowing from Ezekiel's Tyre oracles
details.text: Rev 18 directly echoes Ezekiel 26–27 (merchants/kings weeping, sudden ruin, dust on heads, 'Who is like the great city?'). This intertextual link shows John applying Tyre's judgment as a foreshadowing of Babylon the Great's eschatological destruction.

details.heading: Prophecy's dual near/far application
details.text: Biblical pattern (e.g., Antichrist types in history) allows partial fulfillment historically while reserving full 'never rebuilt' permanence for the end-times entity—ancient Tyre partially judged but 'rebuilt' modestly; Babylon the Great never recovers.

title: Vision to Zechariah
description: On the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month in Darius's second year, Zechariah receives visions symbolizing God's plans for Jerusalem and Israel.

title: Completion of Second Temple
description: The second temple is completed on the third day of the twelfth month (Adar) in Darius's sixth year, restoring worship after the exile.

title: Jews Defend Themselves on Purim
description: On the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the Jews assemble to defend themselves against their enemies as per the reversed decree.

title: Purim Celebration
description: The Jews rest and celebrate on the fourteenth day of the twelfth month, establishing the annual feast of Purim to commemorate their deliverance.
